Award.AwardTitle: DMREF: Computer-aided Design of Hierarchical Molecular Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
DMREF: Computer-aided Design of Hierarchical Molecular Materials

Non-technical Description: Organic materials that spontaneously order into specific architectures could significantly advance our ability to harvest solar energy. However, developing these materials in traditional ways is a tedious process. This project will integrate computer-aided design (CAD), synthesis, and characterization to make a transformative approach in ordered organic materials discovery. An Indiana University team will study packing interactions and develop CAD algorithms for organic architectures. The architectures will form by spontaneous interactions of molecular building blocks programmed with specific features that connect them with neighbors. Resulting architectures will be characterized with state-of-the-art microscopy at single molecule resolution. Those data will be used to improve the design algorithm to reliably predict two-dimensional packing and film growth on surfaces. This algorithm will be implemented as computer software to supersede experiment and thus allow vast speed-ups in the discovery of new organic materials for harvesting solar energy. This work will have a broad impact on many applications of organic materials through free distribution of the design software and through national scientific symposia. The project will also sponsor recruitment of under-represented groups to scientific research careers and outreach to engage high school students in nanoscience education, thus impacting the next generation of scientists.

Technical Description: It is understood that blending two types of organic polymers with 10-20 nm feature sizes is advantageous in photovoltaic devices, but, at present, we do not know how to program organic molecules to form organized bulk heterojunctions with these feature sizes. This project will apply an integrated theory-experiment approach to the programming of molecular self-assembly. Multiscale simulations will be implemented as the core of a materials CAD platform. Innovations in multiscale molecular dynamics will be used to accelerate computation. Batch execution of simulations will be automated by database-backed software. CAD results will be used to design molecules that will be synthesized and allowed to self-assemble at the solution-solid interface. 2D and 3D architectures will be characterized using molecular-resolution scanning tunneling microscopy. Continuous feedback between CAD and the resulting architectures will accelerate the discovery of highly ordered multilayer films. The self-organization of two-component mixtures into alternating domains will be investigated. CAD software will be made available for others to use in the creation of novel organic materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary and Highlights of the Intellectual Merits 

            In the course of our work we explored new hierarchical assemblies of molecules into 2D crystalline arrays on surfaces and 3D functional materials, including the creation of a new class of fluorescent materials. Using an integrated approach that unites synthesis, characterization and simulation together, we showed how molecule-scale dynamics impacts large-scale assembly of molecules at solution-surfaces interfaces. We have created new synthesis methods to make macrocycles of any sequence and used them to identify the design rules governing their 2D assembly on surfaces. We have shown how macrocycle assembly depends on rigidity, intermolecular cooperativity, sidechain adsorption, and monomer sequence. 

We showed how3D hierarchical assembly of molecules is programmed at the molecular level, and tunes charge transport. We reviewed the state of hierarchical assembly. We created a model of ionic assembly and discovered how local ions influence the charge-transfer energies in donor-acceptor assemblies. 

We discovered a new class of hierarchical molecular crystals, called small-molecular ionic isolation lattices (SMILES). In these materials, we found that fluorescence is turned on by adding anion-binding macrocycles to cationic dyes, like rhodamine 3B. The crystal structure shows cationic rhodamine alternating in stacks with two cyanostars hierarchically complexing the dye?s counter anion. The charge-by-charge crystal packing, i.e., (+ ? + ?) for cationic dye / anionic complex, is found to be highly predictable. Crystals of the oxazine, pyridine, cyanine, and triangulenium dye DAOTA all show the same packing and photos of their thin films all show the same intensity turn on. This predictability suggests that design rules can potentially be codified with the aid of studies of ionic assembly in solution, crystal engineering and the optical properties in the various forms of the assemblies. 

The studies of 2D assembly helped advance knowledge and understanding within the field of programmed self-assembly at solution-surface interfaces. The work completed has helped to redefine the role of molecular symmetry on 2D surface patterning. The discovery of a new class of fluorescent materials represents a potentially transformative and original concept in the design of molecular materials. It has the potential to impact the field of programmed self-assembly, as well as different fields, such as, organic nanoparticles, lasing, and optical materials. We have also demonstrated how the integration of 2D surface analysis with atomic-scale molecular dynamics simulations can lead to greater insight into molecular assembly and nano-length and time scales.

 

Broader Impacts: The Broader Impacts criterion encompasses the ways in which the project benefitted society and contributed to the achievement of specific, desired societal outcomes.

We have advanced discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning. To this end, we trained 4 undergrads, 15 grad students, and 3 postdocs. In the course of this training, we have had the chance to broaden participation of under-represented groups with8 women trainees and the training of 2 people who identify as Hispanic. We have also enabled the team to broaden dissemination to enhance understanding. Together, we gave over 100 presentations to communities of interest. We organized a 4-day symposium on ?Hierarchical Self-assembly of Organic Films? (Spring ACS 2017) with 54 speakers. Our outreach has involved NanoScience events at Bloomington?s Wonderlab and multiple outreach activities at Eastern Greene Middle School. Other activities have included graduate student Yang sharing the results of molecular dynamics simulations with pre-service teachers to discuss observation and inference in science. 

 

We have explored other benefits to society that include technology transfer and commercialization activities that include the filing of two patents, cofounding a start-up business, Halophore, that has since secured SBIR phase I funding. Professional training in this area have involved participation in Innovation-Corps. 

 

A total of 22 products have been produced over the course of the project including the 2 patents, and 20 papers. Of note are the two papers that involved synthesis, characterization and modelling working together to address research goals. Moreover, 14 of the publications involved collaborations and represented team-science activities to address the research goals. 

 

            All the experimental and computational data (raw and analyzed) have been made available in publications. DMS software produced in the course of the project for conducting multi-scale simulations has been deposited in GitHub. X-ray crystal data is deposited in the Cambridge Structure Database and spectra have been deposited at fluorophores.org. One of the papers was made available on ChemRxiv.
